The wine list was well created and they had a few great bottles that were very reasonable in price. Their appetizers were great and everything was extremely fresh like they were picking veggies and herbs from a garden in the back of the restaurant. Our main courses were fantastic. Again, everything tasted incredibly fresh and what else would you expect from a good restaurant? A lot of us shared and I have to say there wasn't once plate that I didn't like.

I would encourage everyone to try this place at least once.
author: Gabriel R.

description: Great service, perfect Italiano food, nice atmosphere and wines.. Nothing less than five stars, cant get any better at this price level..
author: Michael P.

description: I'd rate this place 3.5. Food was allright but nothing super exciting.
author: Vladimir P.

description:
I'm going to resort to my ol' standby method of rating: 

(+)
Parking was relatively easy, on a weekday afternoon
Pizza was reaaaly quite good... thin and crispy and the price was right
For a sit down place, I'd probably not go back, but for take out: sure thing.
We were a group of 4, and when we ordered our dessert, he threw in +1 w/o charge because the dessert came in sets of 3..... how sweet.. : ) 

(-)
Fancy pants ambience is right, as Arlene C says... it's not exactly what we were wanting (a group of gals out for a quiet evening out) so I'm debating as to whether it is fair for me to list this as a minus, but for me, it was a minus. 
Pasta that I tasted was not that remarkable... or memorable for that matter...


Overall: not a bad choice.. but probably a better place to take your parents or grandparents, not a place to celebrate with girlfriends!!
author: M'ia K.

description:
3.5 Stars 

I think I enjoyed the service and people here more than I did the meal, although the food was definitely enjoyable. Our server was SO attentive and nice. While trying to figure out what kind of wine I was going to have with dinner, he offered me three glasses with very large "tastes" in them. Not only was it fun to sample the wine but I got entirely drunk on them alone! I just love it when a restaurant goes out of their way to make sure you're getting what you want. It's such a nice feeling to know that your money is being well spent. 

We ordered the Eggplant Parm appetizer to start which was good. I won't go as far as to call it great because it wasn't cooked quite how I like it. I like eggplant when it melts in your mouth and this was a tad chewy. For our main course we split a pizza which was yummy. I would have liked to see the crust on the bottom a little crunchier. It got a little soggy in the cooking process. The dessert was the best part of the meal in my opinion. The profiteroles were fantastic little puffs of pure joy (ice cream and hot fudge). 

The only bothersome part of the meal was this tiny black bug that kept circling our table. Every time I thought I had swatted it into oblivion, some how it found it's way back buzzing in my face. Grrrr....
author: Julia N.

description:
You ever seen Big Night?  Primo, the uber-traditional (read: F.O.B.) Italian chef, refuses to give a customer spaghetti with meatballs because that's not how Italian food is meant to be prepared.  Last night at Pane e Vino, my friend ordered a halibut dish and asked whether the chef could substitute mushrooms for the tomatos in the sauce.  

The waiter  responded by saying that the sauce was already mixed.  Well that was sort of a bad sign...pre-made sauce?  Tell me, what size jar was it in?  But he said the chef would add mushrooms to the fish.

The halibut came out and, no joke, the mushrooms came in a dish on the side.  Why?  Because the chef felt they didn't go with the dish, and they actually took the time to put them in a separate plate.  Now, that is Nick Cannon HI-larious.  What part of "service" industry doesn't this place understand?

To his credit, the waiter was really polite about the whole thing -- it was clearly a chef issue.  But it was a little strange.  My pasta wasn't bad, although the plate of mixed vegetables on the side tasted like it had been microwaved.

So plus stars (1) it's inexpensive and (2) the prosciutto was excellent and the serving generous, and (3) nice decor.  But minus stars for an arrogant chef and, more importantly, a casual Italian restaurant should have more than four choices of red wine by the glass, especially when two of the four are chianti.
author: Geoff K.

description:
I used to love this place -- not any more.  The service last night was abysmal.  They kept us waiting for almost 1/2 hour before taking our orders.  I asked to taste one of their wines and was told "We don't do that".  When I asked the host to recommend a wine he said "No, you choose.  If I choose I know how that will go".  The food was mediocre at best.  Tomato sauce tasted like it came from a jar.  Seafood and fish were not the freshest.   Pasta was very ordinary.

Sad to say -- we will not be returning.
author: Debbie W.

description:
Update: Went back last night, I'd highly recommend the caprese salad as a started, one of the freshest I've had in a long time. My friend and I split a pasta (the excellent fusilli) and then a pizza, which left us nearly over-stuffed, in a good way. This is the sort of Italian eatery every neighborhood should have, and indeed, outside of us, there seemed to be a preponderance of regulars, a nice sign on a Monday evening.

----

Tried this Marina Italian eatery for the first time last night. It's very cozy inside, and you get the sense that the staff is all family. There are a lot of options to try, but I went with the homemade lasagna, which was excellent, and hopefully an indication of the rest of the menu (and why all the tables were full on a Sunday evening). Nothing fancy here, just good honest Italian cuisine, but that says a lot.
author: Nish N.

description: Very good and in a great location on union. We had a pizza for an appetiZer, I had the spaghetti and meatballs and tried some of the other dishes but everything was very good. I thought the portion sizes were a little small (but we didn't do the full 6 course meal). I would order an insalata next time as well but other than that, it was a solid place.
author: Tami G.

description:
I've walked by this place every day since I moved to the neighborhood last February. It's always busy during the evening, and I've noticed happy, laughing, satisfied-looking people coming out of there--never heard so much as a grumble. 

Personally, I'd not been there, because I normally end up flying solo, and it's a white table cloth type of place. I always thought, well, maybe next time... 

A friend was up from So Cal a couple of months ago, and he was going to pick the restaurant. We walked all the way down the south side of Union from Gough to Fillmore, continued up Fillmore to Chestnut, did both sides, checking menus, etc, and all the way back on the north side of Union. The last place before we got back to "go" was Pane E Vino. He must've read 20 menus...he says "This is it!". 

So, yeah, I got to try Pane E Vino finally. We ended up getting bruschetta, which is always good isn't it? And pizza "Napoletana" (tomato sauce, mozzarella, capers, anchovies and oregano)--very yummy. 

I haven't been back, but sometime I probably will. I'm avoiding Italian food for awhile--too many calories!
author: Java G.

description:
Update (decreased review by 2 stars):  Came here last night for a large party.  I was disappointed to see the eggplant appetizer is prepared differently and just not as good.  I'm even more disappointed that the sommelier brought out the wrong bottle of wine, which ended up being $150 dollars/bottle, double the price of the bottle we ordered.  We didn't catch it until it was already opened.  While we probably should have checked the bottle (but, really, who does that), I've never had a restaurant so blatantly mess up on our order and then do nothing about it even when we mentioned the mistake.  It's unprofessional.     
-----------------
The eggplant/smoked mozzarella appetizer is to die for!  This place is very consistent and has good pasta, pizza, etc.
author: Mitzi C.

description: How does this place have 4 stars?  This place is beyond mediocre.  Yeah, the staff is Italian.  Makes them look super legit, right?  NO.  My salad was an overdressed mess.  My pumpkin gnocchi with brown butter and sage came with a huge dollop of tomato sauce.  Know what doesn't go well with brown butter?  Tomato sauce.  The gnocchi themselves did not taste at all like pumpkin.  My boyfriend's pasta (with some kind of beef) was "gamey" and "unpleasant."  We skipped dessert.  It's sad-I remember coming to this place years ago and liking it.  But i've now come 2 times in the last year or so and it is just beyond bad.  We live in a foodie-city.  You can do a lot, lot, lot better than this.  The service was also moving at a glacial pace.  Won't be giving it another "last shot."
author: K H.

description:
Maybe it's because they were closing in less than an hour. Maybe it's because I was wearing a hat and both E-Class and I rocked hoodies. Whatever the reason, Pane E Vino didn't seem very happy to have us.

The guy who seated us looked disappointed, and our waiter seemed annoyed when E was not ready to order two minutes after we arrived. He eventually seemed to warm up to us, but maybe that's because time heals all wounds - he ignored us from after our food was served until we were finished. I was THIRSTY.

So yeah, the service kinda blew. The food, on the other hand, was pretty darn good. I had my first cheeseless pizza, which was tasty but could have used, um, cheese. My bad. E had something with mushrooms and it was delicious. Weird, cuz I almost always pick the better dish whenever I go out to dinner with people. 

We agreed afterward that we should have split one pizza - we would have saved some dough and possibly looked a little gay, which is always sweet.
author: Trey C.

description:
We recently had our wedding rehearsal dinner here, and if a restaurant can please both my picky Italian family, and me and my vegan husband, then it's a winner in my book.

They put us in their private room in the back, which was the perfect space for a big, casual dinner. They were very accommodating and took great care of us. It seemed like every time we turned around our glasses were being re-filled and there was new delicious food.

I don't really hang out on Union Street much, and they only have a few veggie dishes, but definitely a great family restaurant and a good compromise when you find yourself with omnivores. The service is what sells it though.
author: Sharon T.

description:
With all the sub-par Italian restaurants on Union St, its easy to associate this one as part of the bunch. But from the past several times Ive eaten there, this restaurant stands out and gives North Beach a run for it's money.

Im like Poppa Shanley and judge the quality of an Italian retaurant by the strength of their meat sauce. Pane E Vino has a damn good meat sauce!!! My go-to is the egg noodles with meat sauce. It leaves me with a full and happy belly. Raviolis are homemade and awesome, I love the one in the pink sauce. Pizza is fabulous too, so fabulous that when I took my dad here he ate his meal and polished off half my pizza as well. I have always been pleased by their service and they love locals. Great venue for dates and small group gatherings.
author: Heather S.

description:
I almost don't want to write about this place, for fear the lines will get even worse.  It's a special day when I enjoy eating in the Marina.  Usually, I am most displeased by restaurants there and even more displeased at how many people seem to enjoy subpar food in the Marina.  This place is a marked exception: it is superb.  Their pasta is perfectly al dente, their pizza crust is thin and light, and their waitstaff throws in tasteful Italian here and there.  It's the best Italian that side of Russian Hill.

UPDATE '06: subsequent visits have tempered my enthusiasm for Pane E Vino.  The pizza seems thicky and soggier.  What's up?
author: Pamela D.

description: One of the girls I worked with recommended this restaurant to me and I took my husband here for his birthday. Customer service was phenomenal and the staff was so friendly! The food was delish and not too shabby on prices. If you're a fish lover, I recommend their bass. It's not on the menu on the website but it's on their physical menu at the restaurant. At the end of the night some of the staff brought out my husband a tiramisu cake and sang Happy Birthday in Italian! It was perfect with a great audience behind us. Service, food & prices I will give two thumbs up!
author: G P.

description: What's not to like? About a year ago I started going to this restaurant because it is close to my business and I could get in for a nice meal at the end of a busy day. You will always be greeted with a smile and the food is consistently of the freshest quality. Try the spinach salad. It's great, as are the pizzas. Locals fill up the seats, so try and get in early or make a reservation.
author: Roxanne C.

description:
Amazing thin crust pizza.  Try the siciliana with spicy sausage.  I am wishing I saved a slice for this morning.

Warm spinanch salad and flattened chicken breast were also really good.  Some decent house wines and its really hard not to leave this place happy.
author: Brad C.

description:
Pane e Vino has the most delicious pasta and risotto in the City.

I particularly enjoy the fettucini bolognese or with mushrroms and truffles, the risotto with wild mushrooms and the gnocchi with green sauce or with fresh tomato sauce,

Bruno also does agreat Branzino witt garlic and fennel
author: Kath A.

description: We hadn't been to Pane e Vino in about 10 years, and I was skeptical about it since it had fallen off our radar.  We could not have had a better dining experience!  The food was delicious, the waiter was awesome, and the bill very reasonable.  They got the whole back room to sing Happy Birthday the b-day boy.  To think I had written this place off for all these years.  We'll definitely be going back!
author: Beth D.

description:
Another neighborhood gem! I've been going to Pane e Vino for many years now and back when it was known as Via Vai.  The owners closed their other location further down on Union St and combined the two. This restaurant is definitely a place for solid Italian cuisine combined with an authentic serving staff. 

Now I've actually played the "who has the best pizza in town" game and upon visiting the classic favorites incl. Delfina and A16, I always come back to Pane e Vino for their authentic, Italian thin crust pizza. It, truly is the best you can find in SF. They've got about 15 difft pizzas to select from and it's hard to go wrong. I've had the margherita, sicilliana, and capricciosa and they're all winners. If you're looking for something really special - get the quattro formaggi and add prosciutto. The pizzas are a fairly good size so remember to share!

More favorites of mine include the housemade lasagna, ravioli, spinach salad, and the roasted chicken. If you don't know Italian reds too well, consider bringing your own ($20 corkage).

Whether you're looking for a romantic date night, authentic Italian cuisine, casual dinner spot, or just some good take out - keep Pane e Vino in mind.
author: Josephine H.

description:
I liked this restaurant when it was located on Steiner street at the current Terzo location.  It had a cozy feel and lovely outdoor herb garden.  The pasta was really good, fish selection was nice, and the portions were not overly huge.  I have only been to the current location once but I am giving it four stars because I was incredibly impressed by their pizza.

This is a pizza like no other.  A16 gets rave reviews for their pizza, but personally I wasn't thrilled.  I once offered up my A16 pizza to a homeless man who turned it down.  What to think on this?  The pizza at Pane et Vino is different than any pizza I have had.  It has a generous amount of cheese, but not too much.  I ordered a pizza that had prociutto on it, and vegetables as well, and my vegetarian dining companion was able to eat the other half because they miraculously separated!  The cheese and prociuttto were fresh , the cheese melt in your mouth, and the crust perfectly thin.  I think this is the best pizza in the city!
author: apple r.

description:
I've only been here once, but if the next time I go its anything like the first, 5 stars all the way!

A regular at the BStop happens to be a chef here, so I thought, hey why not go visit Bruno and bring my parents and one of my dad's (British) colleagues along (who happens to have a holiday house on the Amalfi  Coast, ergo he knows Italian) and get a free meal outta the situation.  SHAMON.

We walk in and I immediately go over to say hi to Bruno, then take a seat and prepare myself for deliciousness.  Next thing I know we have some prosciutto ham on sticks or whatever it was coming our way and it was made by the Man just for us.  It was AMAZING.  If it were possible, my entire meal would be pig on a stick.

The rest of the meal was fab, and I walked out of there about 10 lbs heavier and high off good vibes.  The actual restaurant is a little tiny and can get crowded, but I didn't notice that much since my face was in my food all night long.  I don't know if it was expensive because, well, the parents paid.  Duh.  BTW, the Brit said the food was legit, so it must be authentic.
author: Erika C.

description:
My first night in San Francisco (this would be about 3 years ago), I moved into a house on Scott and Union and a friend of mine who seems to know every great Italian place on earth said, "there's a great Italian place near here, let's go."  Hey, when Babe Ruth wants to have a catch, you have a catch, know'm sayin'?  So there we went.  It was a Tuesday evening.

We ordered bruschetta and calamari, primi piattis and secundi piattis, and had a meal as good as any I've had in Florence or Rome, and with the same portions, which (in my experience) is almost impossible to come by.

The thing that really grabbed me, though, was this woman and her fourth grade daughter who were having dinner and doing homework at the bar, enjoying each other's company and living their lives in a sophisticated but low-key place that catered to their needs in a relaxed, professional way.  It's what makes Pane e Vino special, a high-class neighborhood joint serving terrific food and wine without being all uppity about it.  It's a snapshot of what I love about living in a city.  Who says you can't have it all?  Not Pane e Vino, that's for sure.
author: John H.

description:
well it was pretty good.  the service was great, which made up a bit for the food.  i'm not saying the food was bad - just not the italian i'm used to.  i have a feeling i'll be back again.

ps - if you get a table it the back, make sure you have a t shirt underneath you because it is hot.  i would have been comfortable in my underwear and a personal fan blowing on me but apparently you can't do that in public.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: We've really enjoyed Pane E Vino over the years (previously Via Vai) and still love the kitchen and dinners served. But I have to pull 2 stars off the rating currently on service. For the first time, my wife and I had pressure to turn over the table. The service staff took my salad plate before my wife finished hers. Bad tone on pressuring the other person at the table. Then brought the dinners before she was done. We had a bottle of wine and expected a normal leisurely dinner, but even the dinner plates were under pressure to be removed and we had to request the water glasses to be re-filled. It wasn't our normal Pane E Vino experience, so maybe it was a one off and we'll go back to 4-5 stars next time. Time will tell, but it will be hard to convince my wife to go back anytime soon.
author: Jon G.

description: Their bolonese sauce was very tasty, not the run of the mill type, their spinach and egg pasta was fresh and cooked perfectly. I will say that the dessert course was the kicker! We enjoyed the warm and golden ambiance, yet I think the noise level could have been louder than "average." But this was a Friday night and one couldn't possibly expect a room full of Italians to be any less vocal :) All in all if you're in the area check this place out.
author: Michelle F.

description: Hadn't been to Pane E Vino for over 15 years, since they were on Fillmore street.  Brought the kids and had a fabulous, authentic Italian meal.  Everything we had was well executed, from the minestrone soup to the housemade gnocchi.  I loved the atmosphere--all the waiters speaker Italian, and many of the customers speaking Italian.  Lots of regulars in the crowd.  The restaurant had a great, warm neighborhood feeling that was so nice to be a part of.  Very nice for families.  We were a party of 5 and had the circular booth, which was perfect.  A really good Italian meal in a city full of pretty lackluster Italian food.
author: Mae O.

description:
I came here on Valentine's day with my boyfriend - we were just walking around looking for somewhere to drop in (with no particular place in mind, no reservations, dressed in jeans an hoodies)... we walked in, were greeted warmly by the host and ushered to our table on the back patio within 5 minutes.   ------ 5 minutes..... on Valentine's day...

Star #1 - No wait - see above.

Star #2 - Service was impeccable.  Our waiter was friendly and knew the menu well.  He was able to recommend wine and the best dishes, and was attentive to us even while it was very busy.  There's nothing worse than asking a server for recommendations and having them not know about the menu or not care about the people dining.  Oh, and our server was Italian, *bonus.  And... even though we were dressed very casual we weren't paid less attention to because of it.  

Star #3 - The food and wine was really really good - we picked a Pinot Nero from Italy that was better than I was expecting for being one of the cheapest bottles on the menu - $38.  I'll be looking for it in stores.  The food was plentiful, flavorful, warm and delicious.  I had the basic salad which was better than expected - and the farfalle salmone (bow-tie)with sun-dried tomatoes and peas in a tomato cream sauce - b o m b.  It was rich and delicious and I was full before getting halfway through it.  I'm looking forward to eating it again tonight as left-overs.  He had prosciutto wrapped asparagus and a mushroom/chicken/cream sauce pasta that was also very good.  The asparagus was to die for.  

Star #4 - The crowd was mellow, and of all ages.  I like going to restaurants where there are older couples, families, young couples on dates, and groups of friends.  There was a lot of variety, so I know it's a great place for any occasion.  The tables aren't too close to each other either - we were able to have a private conversation without thinking other people were listening or having to whisper.  It wasn't too loud, and the music was delightful - they played Pavarotti! I hate having to talk louder than normal to have a convo or be watchful of the people next to you hearing your every word.  The ambiance was perfect.

Why no 5th Star?  - The bus boys were a little clueless - I saw them delivering tea/coffee to the wrong tables, my doggie bag was given to someone else (before I hollered that it was mine) and one kid dropped a knife on our table.  Some might have been upset with it but we didn't mind - we're pretty easy going.  

Overall, a great experience for a last minute decision on Valentine's Day.  I'm looking forward to the next time I dine at Pane e Vino.
author: Alice H.

description:
This is one of my favorite italian restaurants because we really like the food and service.  We're pseudo-regulars and I tend to order the same thing every time I'm there.  Lame, I know, but holy boboli....the tagliatelle verdi alla bolognese is melt in your mouth goodness.  The pasta is Always so fresh.  I've ordered bolognese elsewhere but it never compares to pane e vino's.

We do occasionally order different things off the menu and the  lambchop special last night was AMAZING.  It's not on their regular menu so I hope it shows up as a nightly special again.  I'm not normally a big fan of lamb, but this was AMAZING.

Lots of good desserts too!  The eggless flan is a favorite.

There's usually not much waiting involved to get a table here, but on Friday and Saturday nights, it's always a good idea to make a reservation.
author: Lisa C.

description:
THE BEST AUTHENTIC ITALIAN RESTAURANT IN SAN FRANCISCO!!
My boyfriend is Italian and he's very picky about Italian food. 
The wait staff ALL have Italian accents and I can't pronounce the food on the menu because they are all in Italian. The waiters get a kick out of me trying to pronounce them! The food is fabulous, real authentic and a great selection of wine. Expect to pay about $25 per person (not including dessert). We've been here twice in one week! That should say a lot!
author: Dhoris P.

description:
I love coming here with my bf and his family for dinner, its not fussy, the food is always consistent and good and the servers are all very nice. 

The pizzas are delicious I think they are great for sharing as a starter, they always have excellent burrata and I like to get the osso bucco if they have it (its part of the specials). Other than that for the main course they do a great half roast chicken and you can never really go wrong with pasta.

This is a very decent choice for a low key yet nice italian experience I frequently have cravings for this place...the menu is pretty large and so are the daily specials so you will never be bored with only a few options.
author: Cristina F.

description: I went to this fabulous restaurant last night for the first time. I had a large group and they handled us with ease. All of the food was fantastic and I would highly recommend it to anyone. The employees have great hospitality. Great restaurant.
author: John D.

description: I've been to Pane E Vino multiple times and just had it for take out the other night.  It's good Italian food and a comfortable space.  Nothing fancy about the place or the food but is somewhere I would definitely eat again as it is reliable.  I would recommend the pizzas here.
author: Blake B.

description: AMAZINGLY authentic Italian food selection. Wow. I want to go right now just thinking about their pasta dishes, mushroom and polenta appetizers and thin crust pizzas. Just go, and anything you get you'll be happy with- not one of those places where you can't find anything on the menu that looks good.  Friendly service and the waitstaff are very enthusiastic about the menu.  The calamari is also insanely tasty!
author: Christina V.

description: My favorite place on Union street!! My first time here I ordered the 4 cheese pizza and the truffle mushroom pasta and I was blown away.  I have tried some of their other dishes as well (gnocchi, etc.) but the truffle pasta and 4 cheese pizza are my favorite.  Note: I am biased because I LOVE truffles.  Amazing food and Italian elegance.
author: Nick M.

description:
Cappelini pomodoro was good! Garlic tasting because the oil has garlic in it, but you don't get garlic breath because the garlic is thrown out.  Perfect!  My coworker exclaimed, the veal ravioli changed my life.  Wow. I guess I should eat that next time.  Helen was digging the tiramisu.  

All around really easy going easy on wallet kind of pleasant dinner place.
author: Wakako U.

description: Loved it! Walked in without a reservation on a Saturday night with my mom and they sat us immediately. Great menu and the food we ordered was high quality. We each started with a salad, I ordered a pasta and my mom had salmon for entrees. Will definitely go back because the pizza's looked yummy!
author: Alyssa M.

description: It was the perfect date place to take my girlfriend. The food was beautiful and tasty, and the waiters even say Italian stuff like "Bon Apetit" (or however you spell it).
author: Ben R.

description:
I went on a date here a few days ago and had a really great time!  Good company yes, but the food was pretty good too.  I had a great pasta (on of the fettuccine dishes) and a chicken entree (which was huge).  I was too full for dessert, but will come back for their profiteroles which looked amazing.

It's a great place for a 1st date (romantic, but not over the top).  A very cozy little nook that I plan to visit again soon!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Update:  Revisited the trattoria over the weekend.  Finally tried their pizza.  Impecable.  Prosciutto, funghi, olives, artichokes, parmagiano regiano... Just how they do it in Toscana. Talk about major. Yeah, this is my trattoria. But you may visit as often as you want.

------- 

Hot damn, this is some down home great Italian food.  Pasta dishes are pretty damn tasty and hearty.  I had some pasta alla arrabiata with lobster.  Fuuuuuuuuuck... now that's good eatin'.   I'll be trying their pizze as soon as I can get back there, cuz they looked crack-tastic.  Even though prices are gonna be $15 -20 per plate, you get some good food in return.
author: Zo L.

description: My 4th visit to Pane E Vino over a 10 year span. Have had wonderful food every time and great service 3/4 times (the other time was fine, just not great). Last night was there with a party of 4 and we had a fantastic waiter who was attentive, helpful and downright charming. Always sets the stage for a great meal. We were all starving as we were eating a little late and the waiter quickly brought us a basket of warm bread and plate of olive oil; delicious and we just devoured it. We had a range of dishes from a pizza to 2 pastas and one secondi (chicken). Everyone loved their choices and the whole dining experience.
author: Tom C.

description: We liked it very much. This is a local restaurant to go with your family. We had a Prosciutto Cotto e Funghi pizza and a Tiramissu for the desert. Wonderful taste,  good price and good ambience. It was Saturday 8:30 PM we had no reservation. there was no need to wait. I definitely recommend.
author: Flavio G.

description:
A gf from out of town and I wanted a nice place to relax, stuff our face with pasta, and get a wine buzz. I picked Italian because sometimes my fellow Virginians aren't quite ready for the diversity of SF cuisine.

I made a reservation with Pane E Vino, and we were seated promptly. We inhaled the bread they gave us and then chowed down on our pasta. I got the seafood linguine and it was fabulous. My friend got the fettuccine and it was like eating butter, in a good way. 

And because when in an Italian restaurant, order the Tiramisu; we did and it was so delicious. I will def. come back here again!
author: Chrissy L.

description: We have visited Pane e Vino nearly every time we come to San Francisco for the past 15 years.  This time we were sorely disappointed.  The service was terrible and the food was worse... nothing Italian about it.  The presentation was totally unattractive and I have tasted better in a TV dinner.  My daughter's dish had frozen peas and carrots... nothing fresh, and my sugo tasted like reconstituted hamburger with sauce from a can.  Utterly disgusting.  We will not be back.
author: Mary J.

description:
I love Pane e Vino with a passion. My European friend came into town wanting some authentic delicious meals so I knew Pane would be the perfect place. Why does it rock my food loving face...
1) I go here for dinner no less than 3 times a month. You never have to wait for a table.
2) Great wine list, and honest wine recommendations
3) Our Italian speaking waiter surprised us (after the bill), with a tasty (free!) creme caramel custard.
4) The pizzas are crispy big and perfect for splitting. 
5) The daily risottos melt in your mouth.
If my Euro friend approves then you know its good. Only down side is now I'm so full from pigging out they had to roll me home.
author: Jamie G.

description:
It was crowded, but we were seated promptly. Service was quick and efficient, water glass was always full, staff was helpful and knowledgeable.

We got an antipasto appetizer to share--a random assortment of vegetables like eggplant and cappellini onions, as well as slices of deli meat, including one that was prosciutto wrapped around a thin breadstick--a meat-flavored pocky, if you will. Good plate to share with friends and family.

I ordered sausages with grilled polenta and bell peppers. The grilled polenta was awesome, but the sausages were a little too salty for my taste, but otherwise excellent.

I didn't order wine, but they seemed to have an expansive list. I got an Italian beer instead, which was pretty good too.

Overall awesome Italian place.
author: Josh C.

description:
We had an excellent meal here on Sunday.  My parents were in from out of town, and it was a nice time.  The ambiance is perfect for taking out of town guests for an uncomplicated meal with good food and a nice ambiance for having a conversation (without too much noise).

The chopped salad and pizzas were excellent -- as was the tiramisu.  The pastas were good, but not as tasty as the other things we had ordered.  The prices were reasonable, and the meal wasn't a big "production."

All-in-all, a nice place to go for dinner on Union Street.
author: Kimberly G.

description: If I could give it zero stars I would. I can't understand how this place has received so many four or five star reviews. I think there's something going on behind the scenes to game the system. The food here is horrible! The best tasting thing that we ate was the bread! Everything we ate here was not worth it. My husband said it would have been better had we gone to some chain restaurant like the Olive Garden. I had the Clams and Linguine and it was so tasteless and bland. When we tried to complain to the waiter, he suggested that it was because we had added parmesan cheese to our dish, which made no sense whatsoever. Service wasn't much better than the awful food. We left there feeling taken advantage of. Wasted our money and time and made our evening feel blech!  I was remarking to my husband that if this had been our first date, we might not be together still. BEWARE! It can ruin your evening!
author: Jade C.

description: We walked in early on a Saturday night and were greeted and seated right away.  Excellent meal, excellent service!  The owner/manager spent some time chatting with us and we felt like we made some new friends!  Would definitely go back.
author: Mary W.

description:
This is a great Italian place with a good atmosphere. I come here quite often and always like what I get. Last time we shared the pizza appetizer and some bruschetta. Then I had the veal scaloppine and shared the Lobster risotto. There must have been half a lobster in pieces in there - it was great.
Service is good too.
author: Conny F.

description:
I have been here twice. The first time was a date with a girlfriend and I had just moved to town and she was visiting and we didn't know anything. So this place looked good. 
I honestly can't remember what I had, because this place isn't going to remind you of that quintessential meal you had on the coast of italy, but it is good italian food, prepared well and tasty. 
The service it quite good, i felt like my waiter must have been working there forever he knew it so well and was quite good. 
and it isn't a very loud place, so you can have a nice conversation. basically, if you are looking for an easy casual dining experience that happens to be with italian food, this place fits the bill.
author: Rich B.

description:
Pane E Vino was pretty good.

The food was excellent.  I had raviolli with spinich and ricotta filling, with sage butter and tomato sauce.  The raviolli was tender and delicious.

The service could have been a lot better.  I made a reservation for 7pm for a party of 5.  We got their right on time at 7pm.  They didn't have a table ready for us, so we had to wait  a few minutes.  It wasn't long, and I would have forgiven them, until they led us to our table, which was basically a normal square table for four with a small round table for two put next to it.  It wasn't _that_ big a deal, but a mild annoyance.

Still, the good food trumped any frustrating service so I still gave them 4 stars.  Yum.
author: Joshua E.

description:
3+
The food was good. I liked sitting at the patio in the back on a warm summer evening. It was a big party, maybe 12 people and everything went fine, except for two things: I insulted the gay guy at the other end of the table. (I said he looked like the guy from West Wing. You know, the old guy? He died a while back?) 

Secondly, we brought a bottle of white wine and asked the staff to put it in the fridge. They (and we) forgot to have it served. The next day my honey and I went to pick up the wine and picnic in the park. 'Yes, we have it. Here you go.' 

I was shocked! Shocked! It wasn't even chilled!
author: Michael R.

description:
I had my birthday dinner here and I'm glad I did, because my whole party and I were all very satisfied with our experience.  

The pasta was authentic and very flavorful.  The staff was super friendly and for a second it felt like we were family! haha!  The ambience was a lot better than most of the typical Italian restos you'd find in North Beach.
author: Candice M.

description:
I took my husband to Pan E Vino on Father's Day and it was very disappointing. The "B-Team" was working that day and it looked like the owners had taken the day off. The waiter who greeted us was unfriendly. We made reservations in advance but our table selections were near the open door,  near the bus station or near the table set-up for a party of 10. He gave us our pick in the worst locations. A same size family came in afterwards and they were allowed to sit in a booth. They loaded our small table with water glasses, sugar and carafes etc. so it was very difficult to place down any food dishes. I kept having to ask the busboy to clear the dishes.

My husband and I ate linguine with clams and mussels. The first mussel I ate was under cooked, the second one I ate had a shell in it. So I stopped eating the seafood and ate only the pasta. Later in the evening my husband and I both got sick.

This has been a place where my husband likes to eat. But, I have taken this restaurant off our list of choices. My favorite Italian restaurant is North Beach Restaurant. They have valet parking, they are always open, you can walk in and get a nice  table, the waiters are helpful and friendly, the table size and space around the table is comfortable. The food is always great any day of the week.

If you live in Cow Hollow and are regulars perhaps you will be treated better. And if you dine while the owners are on the premises the food preparation may be cleaner.
author: Maria E.

description:
Excellent food and excellent service - what more could you want?

Veal Chop - superb!  Calzone - enough for two but I ate every bite myself.

The spinach salad was delicioso with plenty of bacon bits - and anything with egg gets my vote.

Another plus - it's quiet! Wow - what a concept when almost every restaurant is so loud you can't have a conversation.

A great date restaurant.
author: Glen R.

description:
Favorite Italian restaurant in the city.

Excellent homemade bolognese pasta.  

Friendly wait-staff, and I never have to wait.
author: Jacob J.

description:
After eating at Pane E Vino (formerly Via Vai) at least 30 times with my buddies, I am finally writing a review. Well, I have been there 30 times...do you think I like it? All kidding aside, there are three great reasons to come here.

1. Staff - They are always cordial to anyone, and more importantly, everyone. You are greeted at the small entry way (with just enough standing room for 6 people) by one of the 3 fantastic hosts there. They make sure you are comfortable and don't have to wait long. On 3 separate occassions, they have allowed us to sit at the bar with a complimentary appetizer to help with the apparently long wait ahead. Once seated, service is friendly, and low pressure while still being attentive. The wait staff (if busy) clearly works together to pick up slack if need be. This makes it better for us, the customer.

2. The Restaurant - It is never too loud, but never too quiet. Large groups can feel as much at home as a few good friends or a couple. The lighting in the restaurant is romantic, but not dim. The aroma of the wood burning ovens is nice, and the seating is fairly comfortable. Even out in the back patio.

3. THE PIZZA - I have heard so many of these New Yorkers talking about our pizza this, our pizza that...blah blah. I'll give it to them, their East Coast pizza is better than our East Coast pizza. BUT THIS IS NOT EAST COAST PIZZA. This is BETTER pizza inspired from countryside villas in ITALY. The crust is crisp and very thin. the sauce is not smothered on like  finger paint, but put on lightly, the ingredients are not Pepperoni and cheese, but Prosciutto, wonderful mushrooms, basil goat cheese, etc. The temperature is always perfect, and it always has that smokey flavor that it should have.

Overall, the appetizers are good, the entree's are good, but the pizza and service are great! Oh and by the way, their wine list is pretty extensive. Prices are definately fair.
author: Michael M.

description:
Caresse was a little tough (both tomatoes and mozzarella)

Eggplant was super cheesy which we liked

Thin crust pizza was delicious (artichoke, mozzarella, prosciutto) 

Ambiance was authentic Italian...better than corny NBeach shops.
author: Jon D.

description: Another great meal.  This place always delivers great meals and service.  They always seem to be able to accommodate last minute resos even for large parties.
author: Bryan M.

description: Soooo OK I went to this place for dinner. The food, the service, Amazing... The only thing was, I was on the worst date of my life when I came here and I was waiting... waiting... waiting for the check and it took a while... I think cause the guy was talking to me the whole time, while I was bored & thinking about how I was on the worst date ever, the waiters took it as a sign that we were not ready... We were ready... Great place to go to for dinner, I highly recommend it... Just went there with a horrible date... haha
author: S. B.

description:
Met two friends here for dinner on election night so it was particularly empty.  The owner/manager was quite friendly and sat us right away.  Our waiter was energetic and knowledgeable.  The wine list was solid and reasonably priced but not outstanding.  I had the Italian sausage on polenta with cooked vegetables.  Nicely executed.  I also had berries with zabaglione sauce.  The berries were fresh but the sauce was a little excessive.  (Should I have expected something different?)

Overall good but not great especially for the price.
author: Matthew O.

description: Love Love Love!! Best Italian food in the city. We just opened a salon across the street (Studio Mod Vellum) and went in there a few times while taking a break from getting set up. The service was excellent, food was delicious, and the owner  welcomed us to the neighborhood with a piece of tiramisu. Cake is one of my favorite foods (along with bacon, which is really sad because I'm a vegetarian) so they are my new bff!
author: Andrea M.

description: Well, this is a restaurant I have been going to for years and this last visit on May 20th proved to be underwhelming indeed. I will not go back. Oh well, perhaps it was an off night.
author: Lori D.

description: Went here with my parents after just moving into the neighborhood and found it an excellent place for dinner. Pretty busy on a wednesday night (not full but enough people to feel like you're not dining alone. The food was great, we all had pasta dishes, the capellini pomodoro was especially good with fresh tomatoes and garlic. Our service was great, had a couple different waiters but both were very accommodating and friendly. Overall I'll definitely be going back!
author: Kara G.

description: To be a yelper is to be willing to make the ultimate sacrifice - sharing a treasured restaurant with others while hoping word-of-mouth won't make it so popular that you can never easily get a table again. So I'll tell you about this gem, but only if you promise to keep it just between us, OK? Now consolidated with Via Vai, Pane e Vino serves regional Italian-style cuisine, featuring simply grilled fresh fish and meats, thin-crusted pizzas, and exceptional pasta dishes, all of it extremely flavorful. Despite the name, man cannot live by bread and wine alone, so start out with the spinach salad, the crisp leaves tossed with warm pancetta and eggs in a balsamic vinger-olive oil dressing. Move on to farfalle (bowtie pasta) with smoked salmon, firm peas, and sun-dried tomatoes in a rich cream sauce. Then dig into a rosemary-scented rib-eye steak with a side of Tuscan beans. End it all with any one of the following - a caramelized apple served with sour cream and almond sauce, profiteroles filled with white chocolate gelato and topped with hot chocolate sauce, or a heavenly tiramisu. Considering the upscale Cow Hollow location and the quality of the food, prices are shockingly low - pastas are $12 and $13, entrees run between $15 and $25, pizzas from $10 to $13, and most desserts are $6. Service is impeccable, and regulars are treated like family (albeit one that still must pay the bill). So go. But remember . . . don't tell another soul.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Yummy!  Appetizers, Entrees and Desserts all delicious.  Crowded most nights, but not super loud.  Affordable and filling.  Best part for us is that it's right around the corner from our apartment.  Definitely worth the visit to this Italian restaurant.  The wait staff is very friendly and efficient.  Pasta is good, but looking forward to tasting the pizza on my next visit!
author: Anjali K.

description: Delicious pizza - paper-thin crust, not greasy...just so good. We went there last night with friends, and were sort of in a rush and the staff was extremely accommodating, friendly and helpful.
author: Kate T.

description: More like 3.5 stars, but I can't quite muster up a 4th...The food is very fresh and the pizzas are delicious. It's a great rainy Sunday night spot when all you feel like doing is making the commitment to a carb induced coma and going home to watch American Idol on Tivo. The crowd was a bit too old for my taste and I felt a bit out of place surrounded by all of the large,  boisterous families. However, the food was quite good and I would like to give it another shot, perhaps when the 'rents are in town.
author: Kristen D.

description:
ode to gluttony.

my friends had their engagement party here so we had the back room.  the best part though was that we got to try out so many things on the menu since we were a big group.

the bruschettas were good, the mozzarella alla caprese were so fresh, the carpaccio was tasty, as well as the calamari.   the pasta was only ok, nothing special - rigatoni and fettucine but maybe they were the democratic choices for entrees...same can be said for the pizzas - there were a few choices which were all good - thinner crust and not oily.

the engaged couple brought in their own bottles of wines since he is a big wine guy so i can not attest to their wine selection.  over all, i'd probably rate it average but since it was our friends, we had a great time.
author: Anh V.

description:
I came here for the first time well over a year ago on a second date.  My first visit was awesome.  (My date would probably tell you that our dining experience was great because of her.)  Everything was excellent from the eggplant appetizer to the pasta to the wine to the dessert.  I think the only reason I got a third date out of the lovely lass sitting across from me was because of our meal.  (God knows it wasn't because of my scintillating witticism and bon mots.)  Our experience was so great that we eventually returned for a group dinner about a year ago.  Talk about a total 180.  Bad service, sub par food, and a total ripoff job on our wine selection.  We chose one bottle, and they did a bait and switch with another.  This resulted in a $150 bottle of grape juice landing on the table.  Bad form.  This experience so soured the lovely lass mentioned above that we did not return until last week.

Having just returned from my annual Christmas sojourn in Jersey, I was missing Momma's cooking, so I wanted some Italian grub.  Somehow, someway, we ended up in Pane E Vino.  This would be the rubber match.  I was rooting for Pane E Vino to redeem itself.  The lovely lass had it in for the place.  Things started off badly for Pane E Vino when we got there.  The hostess was completely incompetent.  We did not have a reservation, so she was totally befuddled.  She said that she had several groups coming in later with reservations.  Several means three.  I saw four open tables.  I then looked into the reservation book and saw two reservations coming up in the next half hour.  You could see the smoke coming from the hostess's ears over the complexity of this higher math.  She told us to go sit at the bar and have a drink.  We did.  Problem.  It's not a real bar.  And no one asked us if we wanted anything.  

Just as I was about to lose it, our waiter from our very first visit walked by.  If you go, ask for him.  He's the dude with the shaved head and the shirt two sizes too small.  (I have heard that chicks dig this look.)  He immediately began apologizing for the delay, pointed out a table being prepped for us, and told us that it would be ready in a minute or two.  Message  to the owners: fire the incompetent arithmetically challenged wench who was working on Sunday December 30th and give shaved head guy a raise.

From there things were fine.  Our waiter was about 12 years old, but he knew the menu and answered all of our questions.  We ordered a roasted eggplant antipasto that was a special.  It was delicious.  I then had the ravioli special.  It was superb.  It came in a sage butter sauce that was interspersed with a chunky marinara.  This may not sound very good, but believe it was.  Two great tastes that tasted great together.  The lovely lass had the fettuccine with porcini mushrooms.  Also excellent.  The portions were perfect.  We were satiated, but did not roll out the door.  The bill was a little higher than I expected, but we got jacked on 2 glasses of mediocre Sicilian wine.  (Aren't mediocre and Sicilian redundant?  Or is it criminal and Sicilian that are redundant?  I can never get those two straight.)

Congratulations Pane E Vino, you won the rubber match.
author: Chris I.

description: Great neighborhood Italian in Cow Hollow! This place is consistent, has everything you could want on the menu and doesn't break the bank either. Last week I had the chicken but normally I get the sausage pizza. Both are very good as are the pasta dishes. Also, the owners are Italian, the chef is Italian and most of the wait staff are as well. I always feel that adds to the experience when the staff of an ethnic restaurant are of that ethnicity! At first I gave Pane e Vino five stars but when I looked at the rating of "Woohoo, as good as it gets!" I had to bump it down to four. Yes, I am a fan of this place but I can't say it's as good as it gets. Great place for a quick mid week dinner!
author: Jim M.

description: After the glorious ratings here, I thought I should give this place a try... Well, it's mediocre. I had their Antipasto Della Casa - the cured meats were fresh and tasty, but the house-marinated vegetables were so so. And then I tried their Pizza Margherita (really, the first thing one should try in an Italian restaurant). Well, I've had much, much better - and I've spent a month traveling in Italy. Service was attentive and atmosphere is pleasant. But for a much better food go to Capannina!
author: Margarita B.

description:
i know it's going to be a good evening when i can find parking right outside a restaurant when i'm on union st.  i came here on fri night w/ wakako and our other friend, and it was so much fun!  we originally made a reservation for 2 ppl, but our friend decided to join us at the last minute, and we were still seated right away.

we started w/ a half carafe of the house red, and bread was brought to the table right away.  we started off w/ the caprese salad and the spinach salad.  we then shared the capellini al pomodoro, the capricciosa pizza, and a ravioli special, which i didn't try.  i loved the capellini, b/c it was simple w/ lots of fresh tomatoes.  we were originally not going to order this, but we saw the ppl next to us eating it and they highly recommended it!  the pizza was good too, but since there were a ton of toppings on it, it became a bit soggier than i had hoped.

for dessert, we shared the apple streudel and tiramisu.  like wakako said, i ate like 3/4 of the tiramisu myself b/c it was so good.  overall the experience was pleasant, as we got to sit in the back patio and chitchat w/ our neighbors.  service was excellent as well.
author: Helen T.

description: This is a good solid Italian place. I think it's better than Capannina and more consistent. The ravioli are good so are the gnocchi.  I would give them 3.5 stars.
author: T O.

description: Have been there several times in the past months. Love the service, the ambiance and the food. Recommend soft jazz for music instead of pop
author: Barbara H.

description: Pane E Vino was finally picked after an hour of searching for a place to eat, and I'm happy we spent the extra time to find this wonderful Italian neighborhood restaurant. The food is comforting and cooked with an attention to detail and a concern for authenticity. I was in Tuscany in the end of May and I could have been fooled this evening. We shared  the caprese salad, the fusili pasta dish and finally a mushroom pizza. All were satisfying and made me wish that Pane was down the street from my house. Every neighborhood needs a great reasonably priced family style Italian joint. For a Monday this place was close to capacity, I think we got the last seats, so get here a little early or be ready to wait on a busy night.  It's worth the wait.
author: Phil M.

description:
this place should be called pane e pazzo hostess. 

It pains me to write this as I have had some good experiences here, but last nite's mishap is enough to scare me away for good. It's Sunday and I decide i want some good neighborhood italian, I call at 4pm and get reservations for 7:30 for a party of 4 no problem. Or at least that's what the hostess says...

cut to 7:30, I walk in and was ignored by the hostess for a good five minutes, she's dealing with another party of 4, they seemed angry, she seems stressed. She then walks away for 10 minutes, still hasn't said anything to me, by now it's obvious she's avoiding the hostess area. Other people have walked in too, she looks over every now and again and just takes us all in, as we collectively are all annoyed. Finally she walks over and I have to say (to the side of her head), "excuse me, I am here for my 7:30 reservations." She goes, "what?!"  This is the lady I talked to 3 hours previous who took the reservation (I can distinguish her voice), and obviously did not write it down. she just goes, "well it's crazy tonite", and walks away FOR ANOTHER 10 MINUTES. 

Now my party is annoyed as well, finally when she comes back after avoiding us all again, we just ask when we can be seated, at this point we still want to eat at the restaurant and want the simple kindness of being told when we can eat, which 25 minutes into it she has not told us or even hinted that she can tell us. She YELLS back at us, "LOOK IT'S CRAZY TONITE HERE AND I AM ALONE, JUST GIVE ME ONE MINUTE...GIVE ME ONE MINUTE!!!" she obviously had a breakdown, and was screaming excuses to us in a very aggressive manner. All she had to say was, i'm very sorry, here is the situation...we can seat you in x minutes, we will do everything we can. 

We walked out and went to Luisa's and had a great dinner with AMAZING service. i'm glad it worked out because our party of 4 involved my boyfriends parents and who wants to have a bad experience with the 'rents?! 

in my opinion this place has gotten too popular for it's own good, the food is good, but there are other italian options nearby with the same caliber food.
author: Sarah G.

description: I like the pastas here, especially the Risotto and the Farfalle w/smoked Salmon. It can get pretty expensive if you order the Antipasti and desert too. Go for the fancy pants ambience. If you want to go easy on the wallet go to any of several other good Italian restaurants.
author: Arlene C.

description: How is this place getting good reviews?  It's just so overpriced for bland, boring Italian food.  It seems that when it changed locations, it lost its flavor.  Then again, it's just like most (but not all) of the restaurants on Union Street -- not so good.  I guess that when you have a lot of foot traffic you can afford to be mediocre at best.
author: marie m.

description:
Well, though I hate to write a not-so-perfect review, I feel I need to with this place. 

First time we went, about 6 months ago, was with someone who was a SF icon, as well as well known by the owner of this restaurant.  We had a fantastic time, treated with great service, great GREAT food, and just a positive experience.

Last weekend we went again, alone, just the 2 of us.  We felt rushed, the food was good but nothing overly special, and the service was just ok.  We had a lengthy wait for things we asked for (bread, oils, wine, etc.) but never got the feeling like we did the first time we were there.  It made us think that because we had been with someone important, that we were treated that way.  And, when we went ....  just us, it was different.  A little disappointing as the first impression was so amazing.  The last impression wasn't the same, and therefore, we'll probably not rush to go back!
author: J L.

description: had the whole fish there.  It was nice and fresh, tasty sauce, good service.  I give it a solid 3; however, i thought the price/performance was a bit lacking... good back up choice when the other places fill up.
author: andrew t.

description: The pizza here is freaking amazing.  True thin crust with the freshest toppings.  The portions here are not gigantic like my stomach but they aren't skimpy either.  The eggplant parmigiana antipasta dish is probably the best eggplant parmigiana ive ever eaten.  Fattys like me love parmigiana because lots of cheese and sauce really makes the belly grow.  Not only is the food here amazing, but the other diners are my heroes as well.  Sitting next to people talking about how much money they have is freaking awesome.  I wish they would give some to fill my fat ass.  The highlight of the night was a 30 year old asian lady coming in on a date with a 70 year old, balding caucasian male.  I am pretty sure she was either a mail order bride or into his good looks.  I have big titties!  Who wants to take me out to dinner?
author: Fatty A.

description: Consistent, cozy Italian fare.  Delicious wood-fired pizzas.  Friendly staff.  Since consolidating what was once two separate venues (Via Vie and Pane E Vino) into the old Via Vie space, something has been lost from the atmosphere.
author: Amme P.

description: Ok i hadnt been to the new location for this restaurant. My summary: this place is awesome! I moved here from nyc a long time ago and still havent found anything resembling nyc italian in this city. Last night's meal changed my mind.  The prosciutto/mushroom pizza is insane. I will be ordering that as take out. The crust is thin and the taste is superb. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. I also ordered the spinach/ricotta ravioli with marinara sauce and it was equally impressive. My friends had the duck said it was "good"; the lasagna was "good" and the flat noodle with meat sauce was "ok". I guess i was the best orderer in the group! I will be back again and again..you will recognize me as the guy in the corner who looks pregnant.
author: Not M.

description: I actually wish more out of towners would write bad reviews so us locals could have the place to ourselves! Not much to say here except it's our favorite restaurant in our neighborhood. Incredible service...the staff has become friends of ours over the years. Great wine by the glass/carafe list, and the pizza is perfect. Great salads too. Pasta selection is extensive as well. We've had private events for 25+ people in the back room...overall a great value and ambiance.
author: jeff l.

description:
Popped in last night starving after working out  so I was very pleased when my dinner companions decided upon family style and we ordered like crazy. The highlight was the special whole fish, it was done perfectly. Although the sides of 3 new potatoes and veggies were blah. 
Other highlights included the fresh fettuccine with chicken & mushrooms, the risotto and the ravioli. All that and a great bottle wine. I'm glad to see they are still top notch.
author: Cbr A.

description: I really enjoyed coming here. We made a reservation on a Friday at 7pm. We were greeted and seated by a friendly hostess and then greeted by an even friendlier waiter with a very obvious Italian accent. To start we ordered the ANTIPASTO DELLA CASA which was a assortment of cured meats and vegetables. It was good it had a variety of different flavors and spices. For our first course we had the pumpkin gnocchi and it was incredible. My boyfriend ordered the veal shank osso bucco served on risotto. The veal literally melted in your mouth and the risotto was perfectly cooked. I had the chicken breast topped with tomatoes and garlic. The flavor was great but the chicken was a little dry. I would love to go back and try something else.
author: Melanie V.

description: pane and vino is a neighborhood jewel . It has the freshest most wonderful pastas and salads ! It is warm and gracious and fun! It is a great experience and one can not  express how true and fine it is!
author: Claribel j.

description: Went on a Sunday night and was lucky to get a table at 7PM... this place is a local institution.  The key word is pasta and you have lots of choices here, the mushroom ravioli was delicious.  A great casual date night place or just hanging out with old friends.
author: Annabel G.

description: You might think I'm biased b/c I live literally across the street ... but I used to trek all the way down the hill from Pacific Heights before I lived on Union Street.  Hands down my favorite Italian place.  I've gone here for birthdays, dates, going away parties, and even called for take-away.  The waiters are friendly, courteous, and helpful.  The food is good . . . I have too many favorites to list.  YUMMM!  I'm getting hungry for pasta just thinking about it.  Excellent pizzas too!
author: kristen h.

description: I used to love this place and went every week for years.  After they consolidated restaurants and closed the Steiner location, things have not been the same.  Still a great place for an intimate meal, and the dishes are solid.  Most of the specials are good, the pizzas crispy and tasty, and pasta here is fresh.  I think the wait staff is a bit pretentious, which was balanced because the maitradi was great and friendly.  He left, and now you have some snots seating you too.
author: Kapeli M.

description:
Incredible food, incredible service, incredible ambiance.

I agree with the reviewers who weren't sure whether to divulge how great Pane e Vino is.  

The Puttanesca is delicious and full of flavor.   The gnocci is done comfort food style, and the Pizza is a wonderful indulgence.

For two, I recommend splitting a pasta dish and a pizza and trying a few glasses of wine.  My favorite pizza is the one with arugula and prosciutto (be sure to pronounce it "pra-SHOOT").

The desserts are delicious, my favorite is the cheesecake.  It's not to sweet and is among the best I've tried.

Pane e Vino will make you feel like family.
author: Matt M.

description: Went there with a group of 8 and were seated promptly in the atrium in the back; a very pleasant setting. We shared appetizers including the veggie pizza and mixed green salad. The pizza was good with fresh eggplant and bell peppers. The salad was drenched in oil. For the price of the salad ($8 or $9), I expected either fancier greens or larger quantity. For my main course, I had the fusilli con melazane with smoked mozzarella which was on the bland side. It would've been better with less pasta, more eggplant and cheese, more garlic, and a bit more salt. For dessert, I had the flourless chocolate cake which I found dry. Service was friendly and came by frequently to check up on us. Overall it's about 3 to 3.5 stars.
author: Veggie S.

description: Terrible.  The food was nothing thrilling and we waited forever for our meals.  To be honest it tasted like chain food.   Go elsewhere on Union as this is nothing to write home about and skipping it all together would not be a big deal.
author: Nicole F.

description:
(4) I love this place.  i met friends here the other night and had a fantastic meal.  i NEVER go to italian food because i misguidedly think it's all the same.  I had the homemade sausage with pancetta and peppers and it was off the hizzy.  even the bread and olive oil was ridiculous.  we had a couple great desserts, too.  

Everything is fresh and homemade, the staff is authentically interested in your experience and the whole scene is friendly and fun.

We went early, like 630, and were sat right away, though it got packed really quickly on a Friday.
author: Matt S.

description: We have had some nice meals here but the manager was extremely rude to us on our last visit.  We confirmed a reservation with the owner earlier in the day...excited to be bringing our friends to our neighborhood place, and he could not have been nicer.  People without reservations were being seated before us...tourists reviewing the menu outside...leaving no table for us except the drafty one right next to the door.  That was not great ,but the yelling from the manager in response was anything but acceptable. We plan to speak to the owner soon.
author: carrie m.

description: I agree with whomever said that this is a restaurant you go to if you're within walking distance.  Not work hiking around the city for, but very good if you happen to live by.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
I don't know what everyone else is talking about, but this place was out of this world. Normally I look for restaurants on yelp so that I can find new places and not have to go to the same place all the time, but I am definitely going back here... lots of times. I went on a Monday night at like 6:50, and by 7:10 the place was almost completly full! (I must not be the only one who thinks it has such good food)

They give you bread and olive oil... the usual (althuogh the bread was warm = yum), but then we got the bruschetta. ah so good! Hiiighly recommend it! For my main course I got a pasta dish with marinara sauce and eggplant, and added a bunch of parmesan. Oo it was so good!! 

I'm definitely going back to try one of their thin crust pizzas!! ...and some of the other things that sounded delicious. 

I may even go change my other 5 star reviews to 4 stars because pane e vino was definitely better than any other place I've been to recently.
author: Caitlin B.

description: 2.5 stars.  Decent food, but that unfortunately didn't make up for the fact that our water was never full and we didn't see our server after the plates were put in front of us until we waved him down for our check.  It's a little on the cramped side and while the pasta was yummy and tasted home made, it probably wasn't worth the $$.  I'd give it three, my fiance gives it two, therefore we're compromising and giving it a 2.5, probably won't go back again.
author: Chrys W.

description:
Now that's I've been here twice, I can safely say that I love this place. It's not swanky, but the ambiance is perfectly nice. Great place to go when you feel like consuming 10 million calories of yum.  

Service: The service is hand-down fantastic. Both times we made reservations with almost no notice and were able to get tables (although the restaurant seemed quite full). When we showed up fifteen minutes early, (no bar at which to wait) we were graciously shown to our seats and brought menus. The waiter (same waiter both times) was gregarious, helpful, and ever-present, but never intrusive. He recommended a delicious Spanish dessert wine to enjoy with our Tiramisu. 

Food: We ordered a gorgeous Barolo, which they happened to be out of, so they brought us the same wine, but a better year, for the same price.  Wine list had a lot of great Italian choices.  The bread and flavorful olive oil with the wine ... stunning...  
To start, we had the Mozzarella alla Caprese and the Scallops with Grilled Polenta.  The mozzarella was good, the tomatoes and basil fresh, no complaints. The scallops were flavorful, but a bit chewy for my tastes; however, the tomato cream sauce and grilled polenta were incredible. I had to be restrained from licking the plate clean.  
I followed up with the Taglialini with Mushrooms in a Cheese and Cream  sauce -- it's on the specials menu -- get it. So decadent, so creamy, so very, very bad for you. You WILL come back for this. My friend had the margarita pizza, which was also incredible. 
We finished up with the Tiramisu, which we didn't need, but had to have. 

All in all, a great comfortable place to have a nice dinner. Our bill for two was $180, but $100 of that was wine.  There are great vegetarian options, and a vegan option.
author: Michelle M.

description: I absolutely love this place.  I live across the street and eat here about once a week.  We almost always order the same thing: Fusilli con Melazane (the best!!!), Caprase salad & a Margherita pizza and they never disappoint.  We usually order the food to go, but it's nice to eat there as well.  It can get busy though and there isn't a ton of space.  I have yet to eat on the patio in back.  Maybe this summer...
author: Jessica R.

description: I went here last night a Tues for dinner at 8pm. The service was slooowww and very erratic/hectic/messy/poor. The food was very good, but I most likely will not be rushing back anytime soon.
author: Jody K.

description:
My husband and I love this place! We have had a lot of dinners there by ourselves, for birthdays, and other guests visiting. The reason the food tastes so good, is that the chef Bruno Quircini, has a passion for what he does, and it shows in the food. All the food is authentic and always fresh. If you haven't tried their thin crust pizza, it's to die for!
They put great specials on the menu, like lobster, quail, rabbit, just to stay unique, but they have so many things to choose from it's hard to decide. My husband loves their Veal or the Lasagna, and I love their fish specials and the ravioli.
The place is always busy, and we have a lot of friends that go in there. 
You canmake a reservation, and it is a good idea for dinner time.
The service is great and anxiouis to please.
The wine list has a good variety of not only Italian, but wines from all over.
This place is a must for all who love Italian food.
There is also seating in the back enclosed patio area for larger parties.
author: Fog City Girl L.

description:
Consistent food and service for 10 years!!!  I always look forward to dining at Pane Vino.  My favorite dish  is still on the menu . They also have the best  sausage pizza  I have ever eaten.  

For large groups.. you can enjoy the outside patio... which we have done with family, friends, guests from out of state, and even had business meetings there. 

I have always had great, consistent service and I've never had a bad meal.  Yum!! Yum!! Yum!!
author: denise c.

description: This was one of my go-to restaurants in SF back when it was called Via Vai. I think the name has changed but the management, food, experience are pretty much the same. They have a great olive oil (comes with warm bread) that has a grassy taste to it. Their pastas are made with fresh ingredients and their pizzas are fantastic--very thin, light, with high quality toppings. On a busy night it can be a hassle to get seated without a reservation so book ahead. Try the berries for dessert.
author: Toby S.

description: Always trust Pane e Vino.  I know I'll get a good meal with friendly service.  So it's not "true" Italian, but it's as good as it gets.  The pastas are always good.  The meats are cooked perfectly.  I know if I just want a hassle free meal without attitude and snobs, I go to Pane e Vino.  It's never a "scene"...just good food married to a good wine list.  Can't beat that!
author: Sonia C.

description:
This is the first place I've been to since Italy that nailed the Napoletana pizza.  Amazing. 

The first time I went there I had the gnocchi, okay but I'm a harsh critic as I used to live in Italy.  

But the pizza... again, amazing.

They were also very accomodating as I was eating alone and had just come in from the gym - so I appreciate that they treated me the same as the normally-dressed clientele...  I don't make a habit of going to restaurants in gym clothes - but I think it says a lot that they're service was still excellent.
author: Molly R.

description: Nice Italian food in a warm atmosphere. Staff make you feel really welcome. Prices are good for Union Street. Lots of Pacific Heights types so maybe not the trendiest place in the city.
author: Michael B.

description:
One of the few Italian restaurants my picky mother will willingly frequent (trust me, that says a lot) and the only Italian place I will take my friends from Italy.

I've loved this place since I lived near their original Steiner Street location (it still breaks my heart that they moved 8 blocks away).  The wait staff is friendly and attentive but I won't share my favorite waiter's name cause I want to horde him to all to myself cause he treats us like family every time.

They have a wood-fired oven where they cook pizzas and other entrees.  My personal favorites are the insalata mista (a simple mix of greens and shredded leeks w/oil & vinegar), pasta puttanesca (capers, anchiove and olives will never steer you wrong), grilled salmon and when I'm feeling especially gluttonous, the bistecca alla fiorentina.  Seriously, the steak is like something you'd see on the Flintstones and comes with huge portions of sides like yummy beans.  It's really two full meals and could easily be shared or take half home for the next day.  I find that it's helpful to order the meat a bit more rare than you would like (example: I like medium but I order medium rare - this works most times).  All of their desserts are usually delicious but their tiramisu is especially light and yummy.  And if you're a "regular" don't be surprised if they comp you a plate of bruschetta and sometimes wine and/or dessert.

I HEART this place!
author: Gelsomina L.

description: The atmosphere is warm, the service is attentive, and the food is delicious. It's also very convenient, located across the street from my office. Perfetto!
author: Scott W.

description:
Wandered here w/ the BF looking for a good place to eat on a random weekday. It was surprisingly crowded, but we only had to wait 10 mins for a table. 
- homemade pasta was amazing
- wine was decent
- service was very friendly and they had good opinions/suggestions about what I should order
author: Stephanie P.

description: Such a great neighborhood standby!! Wonderful service, amazing pizzas!!!! Affordable wine...the Seghesio Zin is fantastic for $36 per bottle.
author: CMF l.

description:
Could not have had a better evening!!!  Pane e Vino is tops in my book.
The food and service were superb.  Hands down this place is delicioso!!!  It serves actual ITALIAN food.  What flavor...what taste!!!
Ask to be seated in Fabio's station, he will show you what ITALIAN hospitality is all about.  
Enjoy!!!
Ciao
author: John M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city.  Conveniently located on Union Street in Cow Hollow, the staff falls all over themselves to provide top notch service.  I opine that it is family owned because I seem to see the same Italian-speaking staff year after year.  My usual - carpaccio followed by the quattro stagioni pizza (proscuitto,mushrooms and artichoke hearts).  MMM - so good.  Also, great for groups.  They have a large back room and are reasonably priced.
author: Katie M.

description: Went to Pane E Vino last night for a friend's birthday. All of us really enjoyed our dining experience there. The waiters are actually Italian, and the menu has lots of interesting choices that you won't see at your typical Italian-American restaurant, like black ink pasta. Other pluses are the ambiance and reasonable prices.
author: Katie D.

description: Great service, excellent wine list, nice ambiance.  The new location on Union is great with more room and nice decor.  The wine list is excellent and don't be afraid to ask the manager for a recommendation.
author: T C.

description: this is my favorite place to eat on union street. in fact, it's my favorite italian in sf besides beretta. the tirolese pizza is AMAZING. the service is great. did i mention the dessert is fantastic? LOVE LOVE this place.
author: Tenika S.

description:
we walked in here without any background knowledge... and it was great!  delicious crusty bread, vegetable thin-crust pizza that was AMAZING (more like a crepe-crust, but in a really good way); spinach raviloli done RIGHT, meaning good balance of flavours, not over-cooked.  great portion sizes, not skimpy.

excellent, warm service.  in a white-tablecloth place, they didn't miss a beat when we rolled in with our toddler, who they had a high-chair for (and proceeded to coo over for the whole meal).  

everyone in the restaurant seemed to be having a genuinely good time and it was clearly a neighbourhood joint.
author: Elmo G.

description: Delicious Italian food served in a cozy but comfortable restaurant in Cow Hollow.  Ideal for a romantic dinner or small gathering of friends.  Not big enough to accomodate a big group, though.
author: Mary C.

description: I agree with Margo B. This place is mediocre at best. Went there last night after unsuccessfully finding a good place in the Marina area that wasn't horribly overpriced (not my favorite hood but had to go to Paper Source so we decided to eat there).The back patio was nice. Food was mediocre, service was awful - we had to ask for everything and they overcharged us by $10 and then gave us $10 in cash because "voiding it would be very difficult" - seemed sketchy after I overheard the table next to us saying they had overcharged her by $16 and they did the same thing - money laundering perhaps? Not going back.
author: M B.

description: I was with a large group for a work dinner, so we ordered pretty much everything on the menu and shared.  No complaints from me!
author: LT B.

description: Pane e vino is one of the best Italian restaurants in the city.
